title: Riemann's paradox: pi = infinity minus infinity

multiple-choice.question: What is the sum of the infinite series 1 - 1/2 + 1/3 - 1/4 + 1/5, ...?
According to the Riemann rearrangement theorem, what can be done to a convergent series whose positive terms add up to ∞ and whose negative terms add up to -∞?

options.label: A
options.text: The series can be rearranged to converge to a single sum.

options.label: B
options.text: The series can be rearranged to diverge.

options.label: C
options.text: The series can be rearranged to converge to any sum.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of subtracting ∞ from ∞ in a controlled manner, as described in the transcript?
What is the name of the mathematician who came up with the Riemann rearrangement theorem?
What is the name of the hypothesis that is currently the most sought-after thing to prove in mathematics?
What is the definition of a convergent series?

options.label: A
options.text: A series that adds up to a finite number.

options.label: B
options.text: A series that adds up to ∞.

options.label: C
options.text: A series that adds up to -∞.

options.label: D
options.text: A series that does not add up to a finite number.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of rearranging the terms of a convergent series?

options.label: A
options.text: The sum of the series changes.

options.label: B
options.text: The sum of the series remains the same.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the type of series that can be rearranged to converge to any sum?
What is the result of bracketing a convergent series?

options.label: A
options.text: The sum of the series changes.

options.label: B
options.text: The sum of the series remains the same.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of bracketing a divergent series?

options.label: D
options.text: The sum of the series changes.

options.text: Enough to match the volume of water in a large ocean

title: What really matters at the end of life | BJ Miller

multiple-choice.question: What event in the speaker's life led to their formal relationship with death and their long run as a patient?

options.label: B
options.text: A climbing accident on a commuter train

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the primary issue with the American healthcare system?

options.label: C
options.text: It was designed with diseases, not people, at its center

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's profession, and what type of medicine do they practice?

options.label: B
options.text: Physician, specializing in hospice and palliative medicine

multiple-choice.question: What is the main distinction the speaker makes between necessary and unnecessary suffering?

options.label: A
options.text: Necessary suffering is physical, while unnecessary suffering is emotional

options.label: B
options.text: Necessary suffering is a natural part of life, while unnecessary suffering is invented by the healthcare system

options.label: C
options.text: Necessary suffering is short-term, while unnecessary suffering is long-term

options.label: D
options.text: Necessary suffering is curable, while unnecessary suffering is incurable

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal in inviting design thinking into the conversation about dying?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a more efficient healthcare system

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce the cost of end-of-life care

options.label: C
options.text: To bring intention and creativity to the experience of dying

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the use of technology in hospice care

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the organization where the speaker works, and what is its mission?

options.label: A
options.text: Zen Hospice Project, providing hospice care to terminally ill patients

options.label: B
options.text: Palliative Care Institute, researching new treatments for chronic illnesses

options.label: C
options.text: End-of-Life Care Center, offering counseling services to grieving families

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker does not mention the name of their organization

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the snowball in the speaker's story?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents the speaker's desire to escape their circumstances

options.label: B
options.text: It symbolizes the beauty and wonder of life, even in difficult moments

options.label: C
options.text: It shows the importance of human connection in times of suffering

options.label: D
options.text: It highlights the need for better pain management in hospitals

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what are the key ingredients needed to create a more humane healthcare system?
What is the speaker's definition of palliative care, and how does it differ from hospice care?

options.label: A
options.text: Palliative care is limited to end-of-life care, while hospice care focuses on comfort and living well at any stage

options.label: B
options.text: Palliative care is only for patients with terminal illnesses, while hospice care is for patients with chronic conditions

options.label: C
options.text: Palliative care is about comfort and living well at any stage, while hospice care is limited to end-of-life care

options.label: D
options.text: Palliative care is a type of treatment, while hospice care is a type of care setting

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final message about death and dying?

options.label: A
options.text: We should fear death and try to avoid it at all costs

options.label: B
options.text: We should accept death as a natural part of life and try to live well despite it

options.label: C
options.text: We should try to solve the problem of death through medical research and technology

options.label: D
options.text: We should ignore death and focus on living in the present moment

title: Cannibalism in the animal kingdom - Bill Schutt

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why spadefoot toad tadpoles cannibalize each other in their ponds?

options.text: To reduce competition for food and increase their chances of survival before the pond dries out

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate the pond's water temperature

options.label: C
options.text: It was limited to certain species of fish

options.label: C
options.text: It promotes the survival of the species by reducing competition and culling the weak

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It is limited to certain species of fish and insects

options.label: D
options.text: It has no benefits for the species

title: The surprising reason birds sing - Partha P. Mitra

options.text: It can sing for hours without stopping.

options.label: B
options.text: To attract mates, defend territory, and strengthen social bonds

options.label: B
options.text: From their fathers or other males

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The young birds sing an innate song that changes over generations

options.label: D

options.label: D
options.text: A connection only through environmental factors

options.label: C
options.text: That humans can only learn through environmental factors

options.label: D
options.text: That humans have a direct, one-to-one mapping of genes to behaviors

options.text: Two tails showed up in a row on his coin.
